body: While the sync is running but before it crashes, can you `ls -l /proc/PID/fd` where PID is the process ID of the running rclone. That will show what rclone is leaking (files or sockets)

@ncw here it is (craches are random so it is not an easy task...)

That looks like it is leaking sockets.

Can you see if [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org/) has the problem too? This has a later version of the storj library.

If it does, then can you capture a goroutine dump while it has used lots of sockets. You'll need to add `--rc` to your command then do

    curl http://localhost:5572/debug/pprof/goroutine?debug=1

Or go to http://localhost:5572/debug/pprof/goroutine?debug=1 in your browser.

With latest beta

```
# rclone --version
rclone v1.56.0-beta.5505.f593558dc
- os/version: ubuntu 20.04 (64 bit)
- os/kernel: 5.4.0-70-generic (x86_64)
- os/type: linux
- os/arch: amd64
- go/version: go1.16.4
- go/linking: static
- go/tags: none
```

I still see these:

```
#       0x170481b       storj.io/uplink/private/ecclient.(*ecClient).dialPiecestore+0x17b       storj.io/uplink@v1.4.6/private/ecclient/client.go:65
#       0x1706c98       storj.io/uplink/private/ecclient.(*ecClient).PutPiece+0x378             storj.io/uplink@v1.4.6/private/ecclient/client.go:219
#       0x1709f5e       storj.io/uplink/private/ecclient.(*ecClient).put.func1+0xde             storj.io/uplink@v1.4.6/private/ecclient/client.go:136

1 @ 0x5921c1 0x4725c1
#       0x5921c0        net.(*netFD).connect.func2+0x0  net/fd_unix.go:117

1 @ 0x766e81 0x4725c1
#       0x766e80        net/http.(*connReader).backgroundRead+0x0       net/http/server.go:691
```

`too many open files` usually happens when the default ulimit for max open files is exceeded. Native Storj protocol opens a large number of TCP connections (each of which is counted as an open file). For a single upload stream you can expect 110 TCP connections to be opened. For a single download stream you can expect 35. This batch of connections will be opened for every 64 MiB segment and you should also expect TCP connections to be reused. If you do many transfers you eventually open a connection to most storage nodes (something like 10000 at the moment). If you have a lot of transfers going on a lot of TCP connections can pile up (partly because connections take non-trivial time to shut down as well).

Often the defaults are too small:

```
 ulimit -a | grep 'open file'
open files                          (-n) 1024
```

You can usually increase it by running `ulimit -n 32768`, but it depends a bit on what your host system is and what the min/max system-side is set to. If you get errors running the above look into how your system configures max open files (e.g. on linux that's usually a sysctl setting).

@calebcase wrote:
> `too many open files` usually happens when the default ulimit for max open files is exceeded. Native Storj protocol opens a large number of TCP connections (each of which is counted as an open file). For a single upload stream you can expect 110 TCP connections to be opened. For a single download stream you can expect 35.

I didn't realise that. We should put some advice about that in the docs and an explanation of what to do if you get `too many open files` errors. If you've set `--transfers` large then the number of TCP connections could add up!

I think on windows the limit will likely be 64k files by default so we don't have to worry there, but I'm not 100% certain.

Indeed, after raising both `fs.file_max` and `ulimit` I have no more errors on a quick test.
I'll do the full sync tonight to confirm this.

Anyone like to prepare a doc update - click the edit button on this page!

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/docs/content/tardigrade.md

issue.title: Warning about `too many open files`
